excerpt: Modern & large-scale displays of Japanese & international art in a circular, glass-walled building.
detail_description: The 21st Century Museum of Contemporary Art, Kanazawa is a popular art museum in Japan known for its modern and large-scale displays of Japanese and international art. The circular glass-walled building was designed without a main entrance to encourage visitors to approach from different directions, mirroring the method recommended for viewing the art inside. The museum features both traveling exhibitions and permanent installations, such as Leandro Elrich's Swimming Pool and the Colour Activity House.
name: Kanazawa 21st Century Museum of Contemporary Art

excerpt: Traditional neighborhood with teahouses where geisha perform, plus shops selling gold-leaf crafts.
detail_description: Higashi Chaya District, also known as The Eastern Teahouse District, is a well-preserved traditional neighborhood in Kanazawa. It features beautifully maintained teahouses and geisha houses that were once frequented by feudal lords and high-ranking officials during the Edo period. Some of these historic buildings have been transformed into restaurants and shops selling local goods, while others remain intact as teahouses for visitors to enjoy.
name: Higashi Chaya District (Eastern Teahouse District)

excerpt: Spacious, indoor complex with stalls selling fresh produce, seafood & meat, plus specialty dishes.
detail_description: Omicho Market, known as the "kitchen of Kanazawa," is a bustling indoor complex with over 170 stalls offering an array of fresh produce, seafood, and meat. The market is particularly famous for its variety of fresh seafood caught in the nearby Sea of Japan, including yellowtail, shrimp available year-round, and crab starting from November. Visitors can also explore shops selling local fruits and vegetables not commonly found elsewhere.
name: Omicho Market

excerpt: Village featuring cobblestone streets & former samurai homes, plus shops & restaurants.
detail_description: Naga-machi District, located on the west side of the city and near Korinbo District, is a charming village known for its cobblestone streets and well-preserved samurai homes. Visitors can explore a collection of restored samurai houses along two picturesque canals, with the option to enter and look around. Walking north along the canal behind Kohrinbo 109 Building and then south along the next canal leads to various restaurants and cafes.
name: Nagamachi Buke Yashiki District

excerpt: One of only 3 'perfect gardens' in Japan, this park is designed to be beautiful during every season.
detail_description: Kenroku-en is one of Japan's most celebrated landscaped gardens, known as one of the country's 'Three Famous Gardens.' The name refers to the six classical elements of an ideal garden, and it offers a seamless transition through sculpted pine trees, stone lanterns, and ponds. Originally part of a castle's grounds, this garden has developed over several hundred years and is designed to be beautiful in every season.
name: Kenroku-en

excerpt: Reconstructed 16th-century castle famous for its extensive surrounding garden, with tours.
detail_description: Kanazawa Castle Park is a reconstructed 16th-century castle that once served as the hereditary residence of the Maeda family before the 'Meiji Restoration.' The park, located in Kanazawa City, Ishikawa Prefecture, features extensive surrounding gardens and is adjacent to Kenliu Garden. Visitors can explore historical structures like Ishikawa Gate and enjoy tours of the area. The park is particularly popular during cherry blossom season when the night cherry blossoms create a stunning display.
name: Kanazawa Castle Park

excerpt: Historic Shinto shrine with a grand entry gate featuring stained glass, a large garden & a pond.
detail_description: Oyama Shrine is a historic Shinto shrine in Kanazawa, Japan. It is dedicated to Maeda Toshiie, the first lord of the local Maeda clan. The shrine features a grand entry gate with stained glass and a large garden with a pond. One of its most distinctive features is the unusual gate, which has Chinese-influenced detailing at the base and a narrow, Dutch-influenced second story that was believed to have once been a lighthouse.
name: Oyama Shrine

excerpt: Museum dedicated to D.T. Suzuki with educational programs, a contemplation space & tranquil gardens.
detail_description: The D.T. Suzuki Museum, located in a quiet alley, is a tribute to the renowned Japanese Buddhist philosopher D.T. Suzuki. The museum offers educational programs and features a contemplation space and serene gardens for visitors to enjoy. It provides an immersive experience into Suzuki's life and his Zen-like philosophy. The museum consists of the Entrance Building, Exhibition Building, and Thinking Building connected by a corridor leading to the Suzuki Dazhuo Pavilion near his birthplace.
name: D.T. Suzuki Museum

detail_description: Kanazawa Station is a popular landmark known for its striking architecture and convenient layout. The station features the impressive Tsuzumi-mon Gate, inspired by the traditional Noh drum, which welcomes travelers with its remarkable design. Additionally, the huge glass Motenashi Dome provides shelter from the elements and adds to the station's allure. Surrounding the station are numerous shopping and dining options, including Kanazawa Forus with seven floors of shops and restaurants.
name: Kanazawa Station

excerpt: Showcase of 500-plus phonographs & over 20,000 records, with regular sound demos & a vinyl library.
detail_description: The Kanazawa Phonograph Museum is a delightful and unique attraction that showcases an extensive collection of over 500 phonographs and more than 20,000 records. Visitors can enjoy regular sound demonstrations and explore a vinyl library at this charming institution. The museum spans three floors, offering a comprehensive journey through the history of phonographs from Thomas Edison's early experiments to modern times. It also features antique radio consoles and a fascinating collection of old photographs.
name: Kanazawa Phonograph Museum

excerpt: Kanazawa is the capital of Ishikawa Prefecture, on Japan’s central Honshu Island. It's known for well-preserved Edo-era districts, art museums and regional handicrafts. Kenrokuen Garden, begun in the 17th century, is celebrated for its classic landscape designs incorporating ponds and streams. Adjacent Kanazawa Castle was built in the 1580s, after the defeat of the Peasant’s Kingdom, Japan's only Buddhist fiefdom.
detail_description: Kanazawa, the capital of Ishikawa Prefecture in Japan, is a city steeped in history and tradition. It boasts well-preserved Edo-era districts, art museums, and regional handicrafts. The famous Kenrokuen Garden, with its classic landscape designs featuring ponds and streams, is a must-see attraction. Kanazawa Castle, built in the 1580s after the defeat of Japan's only Buddhist fiefdom, is also nearby.
name: Kanazawa

detail_description: Nestled near the picturesque Kenrokuen Garden, Kanazawa Castle is a captivating historical site that dates back to the 1580s. Although it lacks a castle tower, visitors can explore its well-preserved walls and gates, offering a glimpse into Japan's rich heritage. The surrounding park provides an immersive experience of ancient life. Restoration work on Ninomaru Palace is underway, promising an enhanced visit in the future.
name: Kanazawa Castle

excerpt: Historic district featuring craft shops, Edo-period teahouses & a museum with tours of the area.
detail_description: Nishi Chaya District is a historic area in Kanazawa, featuring craft shops, Edo-period teahouses, and a museum offering tours of the district. While smaller and less crowded than its eastern counterpart, it still offers a glimpse into the city's affluent past. The district is home to venerated businesses serving the city's elite today, with cozy restaurants and bars waiting to be discovered.
name: Nishi Chaya District

detail_description: "The Old Site of Mr. Kurando Terashima's House" is a historic site in Kanazawa Yuwaku, featuring ten well-preserved buildings including samurai residences, farm houses, and an inn from the Edo period. The former residence of Kurando Terashima, a middle-class samurai, offers insight into the lifestyle of that era. The house retains its original garden with over 300-year-old azaleas that bloom in spring and colorful foliage in autumn.
name: The Old Site of Mr. Kurando Terashima's House
address: 史跡寺島蔵人邸, 10-3 Otemachi, Kanazawa, Ishikawa 920-0912, Japan

excerpt: Displays of red & gold lacquerware, colorful hand-painted porcelain & local embroidery.
detail_description: The Ishikawa Prefectural Museum of Traditional Arts and Crafts in Kanazawa City offers a comprehensive overview of folk crafts in the region. The museum showcases 36 designated traditional crafts, including red & gold lacquerware, hand-painted porcelain, local embroidery, Kutani porcelain, Kaga Yuzen silk, and more. Visitors can explore exhibits related to various speciality crafts in the sleek and well-designed museum located beside Kenrokuen Garden.
name: Ishikawa Prefectural Museum of Traditional Arts and Crafts

excerpt: Small museum featuring 2 Edo period homes & a garden that portray the life of samurai foot soldiers.
detail_description: The Kanazawa City Ashigaru Museum, located in Nagamachi, offers a fascinating glimpse into the lives of lower-caste samurai foot soldiers during the Edo period. The museum features two reconstructed homes and a garden that showcase the relatively austere lifestyle of the ashigaru. Visitors can explore these well-preserved houses to gain insight into how these lower-ranked samurai lived in the past.
name: Kanazawa City Ashigaru Museum

excerpt: Downtown shopping area with department stores, boutiques, global brands & underground parking.
detail_description: Korinbo is the bustling heart of Kanazawa's central commercial and business district, offering a diverse shopping experience. This downtown area features major department stores like Daiwa and shopping complexes such as Korinbo Atrio and Tokyu Square Korinbo. Visitors can explore an array of boutiques, global brands, and fashion outlets at these locations. Additionally, the underground parking facilities make it convenient for shoppers to access the area.
name: Korinbo

detail_description: Kanazawa Castle Ruins is a historic site located in the Ishikawa Prefecture on the Japanese West coast. The city is known for its well-preserved Edo period architecture and offers a number of peaceful attractions for visitors. Some of the must-visit places include Kenrokuen, one of Japan's most beautiful gardens, Nagamachi Samurai District, Kanazawa Shinise Memorial Hall, and various temples and shrines such as Teramachi and Oyama Shrine.
name: Kanazawa Castle Ruins

excerpt: Historic Japanese garden next to Kanazawa Castle with walking paths, a pond & night lighting.
detail_description: Gyokuseninmaru Park is a charming Japanese garden situated adjacent to Kanazawa Castle. The park features a serene pond with three islands, a picturesque waterfall, and a circular walking path adorned with small bridges. Visitors can also enjoy matcha green tea and wagashi sweets at the small tea house within the garden. Despite its proximity to the castle, the park maintains a tranquil atmosphere with limited tourist traffic, making it an ideal spot for relaxation and scenic appreciation.
name: Gyokusenin Maru Garden

detail_description: When visiting Kanazawa, don't miss the Kanazawa Shinise Memorial Hall, located in the Nagamachi Samurai District. This museum offers a glimpse into traditional Chinese pharmacy practices from the Edo-era and showcases a diverse collection of local crafts, including intricately handcrafted temari woven balls. The museum also features rotating exhibitions on local history and crafts. What sets this museum apart is its bilingual signage in Japanese and English, making it accessible to international visitors.
name: Kanazawa Shinise Memorial Hall
